A Look at Military Divorce

Different from civilian divorces, military divorces put into play various situations which complicate the whole divorce process. To start things off, there are Federal laws which prevent someone who is active duty in the military to be divorced with no knowledge of it, as they are protected against being forced to answer a divorce action, or any other civil suit, while on active duty. As a matter of fact, the procedures can be postponed for as much as sixty days after the time of active service; or an active duty service member can decide to waive any delaying if they indeed want the divorce.

When it comes to the spouse, the Federal and state laws are basically the same. If the spouse is on active duty, she must personally receive a summons to the court as well as a copy of the divorce Complaint; if not, the Virginia court will most definitely have no authority over the court case. Whenever the case remains uncontested, the spouse may be served an affidavit whereby they thoroughly recognize the steps taken in terms of divorce.

Typically, the requirements to get a military divorce state that one individual concerned is required to be living or stationed in Virginia. The grounds used for the divorce are exactly the same ones as in a civilian case. As far as property division, the standard Division Of Property Laws employ, not to mention that the government has also put in place the Uniformed Services Former Spouses' Protection Act which has the purpose to figure out who should get how much military retirement benefits upon divorce. However, the military retirement funds may be the subject of an exception if the spouse has been married for less than ten years while the military spouse was on active duty.

In case there are children involved in the case, the child support laws and regulations say that alimony plus child support are not to be greater than 60% of a military member's pay. The regular process is used to set how much a member pays for child support in case of a divorce.
